p: Virus detection is made with nasopharyngeal swabbing, which might cause the patient to sneeze, exposing the healthcare worker to infection. Throat swabbing is easier, but viral titres are lower (Zou et al ., 2020), which leads to a lower sensitivity of the diagnostic test. Early morning saliva coughed up by clearing the throat after wake‐up, sampled by the test person and sent to a diagnostic centre is more sure. Viral titres paralleled those in endotracheal aspirates, albeit at a 10‐fold lower viral titre (To et al ., 2020).
